metadata./Title: Successful management of mycotic anastomotic pseudoaneurysm of interposition vein graft following a carotid endarterectomy: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Anastomotic pseudoaneurysms of interposition vein grafts are a rare entity that requires urgent management to prevent life-threatening complications, such as rupture and thromboembolism, especially when involving the carotid arteries. As these are rare complications and literature is sparse, we believe that this case report can aid 
the decision-making process in similar circumstances.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 49-year-old Ukrainian male patient presented with a false aneurysm of both distal and proximal anastomosis of an interposition vein graft between the common carotid artery and the internal carotid artery, 
which was previously performed as a bailout procedure after the patient developed a complication of carotid surgery. 
The patient was successfully treated with extra-anatomical interposition of a vein graft from the subclavian artery 
to the remnant of extracranial internal carotid artery and en bloc excision of the previous vein graft with the false 
aneurysms.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Mycotic anastomotic pseudoaneurysms following carotid endarterectomy represent a rare yet serious 
complication in vascular surgery that requires urgent treatment. While endovascular techniques could represent 
an alternative option, open surgical repair is still the standard of care for this pathology, offering advantages in pre venting postoperative ischemic complications and ensuring optimal long-term outcomes. The open approach 
provides direct visualization of the pseudoaneurysm. It allows the meticulous debridement of the infected tissues 
and an accurate reconstruction of the arterial wall with autologous or synthetic grafts. In light of the substantial 
evidence supporting its superiority, open surgical repair should remain the preferred approach in addressing mycotic 
anastomotic pseudoaneurysms following carotid endarterectomy. Future research should continue to explore 
advancements in other surgical techniques and refine treatment strategies to enhance patient outcomes in this challenging clinical scenario.

sections.Introduction:
Introduction
Anastomotic pseudoaneurysms are rare complications 
of any vascular reconstruction and require prompt man agement to prevent life-threatening complications, such 
as rupture and thromboembolism [1]. The available lit erature mainly describes anastomotic pseudoaneurysms in the inguinal region or involving reconstructed vis ceral arteries [1, 2]. Although considered relatively safe, 
carotid endarterectomy can be complicated by pseudoa neurysm formation, which is potentially life-threatening

[3]. Pseudoaneurysms occurrence is mainly attributed to 
arterial wall degeneration, intraoperative arterial dam age, suture line disruption, and infection [4, 5]. This case 
report presents the successful management of anasto motic pseudoaneurysms of both the distal and proximal 
anastomoses of an interposition vein graft between the 
CCA and the ICA. The original interposition graft was 
performed as a bailout procedure after the patient devel oped a complication of carotid surgery. We performed 
revisional surgery, which involved en bloc excision of the 
vein graft with the pseudoaneurysms and subsequent 
interposition of a new extra-anatomical vein graft from 
the subclavian artery to the remnant extracranial ICA. 
Owing to the lack of data in published literature and 
the rarity of this complication, we believe that this case 
report can be helpful in guiding the decision-making 
process in similar circumstances.
Case presentation
A 49-year-old Ukrainian male presented to our hospi tal with false aneurysms of both the distal and proximal 
anastomoses of an interposition vein graft between the 
common carotid artery (CCA) and the internal carotid 
artery (ICA) 3 months after the index operation.
The patient initially presented to a military hospital 
with an ischemic stroke that occurred during military 
action. The preoperative imaging showed an ischemic 
area in the territory of the middle cerebral artery, a 90% 
stenosis of the left ICA according to NASCET crite ria, and a 65% stenosis of the right ICA. He underwent 
an emergency endarterectomy and bovine pericardial 
patch. On the postoperative day (POD) 18, the patient experienced sudden pain and swelling at the surgical site 
associated with leaking blood through the site of a prior 
drain. He was urgently returned to the theater where 
active bleeding was identified from a total disruption 
of the patch suture line. Ligation of the external carotid 
artery and interposition vein grafting from the CCA 
to the ICA was performed. On POD 8 after the relook 
surgery, the patient sustained temporary loss of con sciousness and raised temperature. An urgent magnetic 
resonance image (MRI) of the brain was performed but 
no new changes were reported. The patient was subse quently transferred to another medical facility where a 
carotid ultrasound demonstrated a false aneurysm of 
both distal and proximal anastomoses of the interposi tion vein graft.
After admission to our facility, the patient underwent 
a thorough preoperative workup. Pseudoaneurysms of 
interposition vein graft were confirmed on computed 
tomography (CT) scan, which is demonstrated in Fig.  1. 
The operation was performed under general anesthesia. 
The first stage was an extra-anatomical interposition of 
vein grafting from the subclavian artery to the 15  mm 
long remaining extracranial internal carotid artery 
(Fig.  2). The second stage was excision of the pre-existing 
vein graft and the false aneurysm and wound drainage 
(Figs. 3, 4).
The patient was started on linezolid and cefepine and 
the surgery was performed as planned. As a postop erative anticoagulation patient was prescribed cilostazol 
200 mg daily and triflusal 600 mg daily.

sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Anastomotic pseudoaneurysm formation, though 
uncommon, occurs in 2–5% of patients undergoing arte rial reconstruction [1]. Whilst literature mainly focuses 
on pseudoaneurysms in the femoral region, sporadic

cases involving reconstructed visceral arteries are also 
reported [ 2].
Pseudoaneurysms (PAs) following carotid endarterec tomy (CEA) are rare but potentially life-threatening com plications, with a very low incidence ranging from 0.3% 
to 0.6% [3].
Factors contributing to pseudoaneurysm formation 
include arterial wall degeneration, intraoperative arterial 
damage, suture line disruption and infection [4]. Infec tions complicate approximately one-third of all post-CEA 
pseudoaneurysms [5]. This diagnosis should be consid ered early when patients present with persistent hema toma, recurrent bleeding from the wound, or late wound 
infection [6].Despite an unestablished rate of rupture, surgical inter vention is recommended to prevent rupture or throm boembolism [7]. Open surgical repair remains the gold 
standard approach, offering several advantages over 
endovascular techniques. In a study by El-Sabrout et al., 
the authors retrospectively reviewed a series of infected 
post-carotid endarterectomy pseudoaneurysms and con cluded that open surgical repair resulted in satisfactory 
outcomes [4]. Similarly a further case series, Ahuja and 
Tefera reported successful outcomes with open surgical 
repair [6].
Open surgical repair provides several benefits: it allows 
for direct visualization of the pseudoaneurysm, thorough 
debridement of infected tissues, and meticulous recon struction of the arterial wall with autologous or synthetic

grafts [8]. Moreover, it reduces the risk of recurrent 
infection and embolic complications associated with 
endovascular techniques [9]. Ocal et al. demonstrated 
the effectiveness of hybrid vascular techniques in manag ing complex cervical carotid artery aneurysms, highlight ing the importance of personalized treatments [7].
In conclusion, mycotic anastomotic pseudoaneurysms 
following carotid endarterectomy are rare but serious 
complications that require expedited treatment. Open 
surgical repair remains the cornerstone of their manage ment, offering superior long-term outcomes and mini mizing the risk of postoperative complications [1].
Conclusions
Mycotic anastomotic pseudoaneurysms following carotid 
endarterectomy represent rare yet grave complications 
that demand urgent attention. While endovascular tech niques could be considered as an alternative approach, 
open surgical repair remains the gold standard of man agement, offering unparalleled advantages in prevent ing postoperative ischemic complications and ensuring 
optimal long-term outcomes. The efficacy of open repair 
is granted by the direct visualization of the pseudoaneu rysm, meticulous debridement of infected tissues, and 
precise reconstruction of the arterial wall with autolo gous or synthetic grafts. In light of the substantial evi dence supporting its superiority, open surgical repair 
should remain the preferred approach in addressing 
mycotic anastomotic pseudoaneurysms following carotid 
endarterectomy. Future research should continue to 
explore advancements in surgical techniques and refine 
treatment strategies to further enhance patient outcomes 
in this challenging clinical scenario.
